Contact definitions allow the major incident manager or the incident response teams to focus on incident resolution and not spend time identifying stakeholders and impacted users who need to receive communications.

Three types of communication contact definitions can be defined for a communication plan:

  • User: Depending on the communication plan, you can add individual users to receive communications for a major incident. For example, a duty manager and an incident manager should always get an initial notification when a major incident is created.
  • Group: Identifying groups that should be involved or informed for various types of incidents can now be predefined so that the members can be notified automatically when a major incident occurs. An example would be to notify Service Desk about all major incidents as they are created and to send them regular status updates. In some cases, it can be helpful to involve other teams, such as Legal, Compliance, and so on.
  • Recipient list: With recipient lists, you can create a static or dynamic list of users who should be notified as per the communication plan. Examples of recipient lists include:
    • Impacted users by location: A recipient list to notify impacted users based on a location. This dynamic list is created using a condition builder.
    • Business stakeholders: A recipient list to notify service owners of impacted services. This is another example of a dynamic list that is created using a script.
